author: sebastiengllmt
title: Catalyst SDK dRep support
description: Cardano will be introducing dRep support for Catalyst. However, at the moment, there is no SDK for wallets and projects to implement dRep support

f6_assessments.q0: Cardano will be introducing dRep support for Catalyst. And I agree with proposers that at the moment, there is no SDK for wallets and projects to implement dRep support. Moreover the whole concept of dReps is not well promoted and explained. I think this proposal can effectively address the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: The team is highly experienced. I didn’t know they wrote Catalyst registration SDK and were involved in the creation of the both the original Catalyst registration CIP along with its recent update for dRep support. But I know many other projects of this team such as Flint wallet. Therefore I have no doubts in the success and quality of this proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: The sccess will be the release of the SDK and hopefully soon we’ll see the dRep support for future Catalyst rounds and also proper integration in wallets, not only in Flint, but in Yoroi, Lace, Eternl and others. Taking to account the experience of this team with other Catalyst projects, there are few doubts will see the progress very soon.

f6_assessments.q0:
The dcSpark team has identified an important technical deficiency with the upcoming dRep onboarding and deployment - a complete lack of SDK for wallets and projects that would help in implementing dRep support.
Since they are also the developers of one of Cardano’s light wallets, Flint, from my understanding they will be introducing this feature first with it. However, the SDK will also be made publicly available to any project interested in adding Catalyst registration support and dRep registration. This is a very important aspect of the proposal, most important because there are several wallets popular across the community, not just one. As such, the exposure of the community to the dRep onboarding will increase exponentially if other wallet and project developers will follow suit.
As someone deeply invested in the Cardano ecosystem, I think this proposal is very appropriate, not just for this challenge but also for the overall upcoming changes within the Cardano Ecosystem, as without wallet integration, the dRep onboarding process would take longer to start. The work presented in this proposal will speed up development, and help the ecosystem be ready right from the start.
As such, I view this proposal as having great potential and can prove to be highly impactful.
f6_assessments.q1:
Now, as much as I appreciate the solution offered in this proposal and the entire work of the dcSpark team with Milkomeda, CIP editing and everything else, as the list would be too long to include in a proposal assessment, the lack of interest in providing a reasonable amount of information in the feasibility section is to me, slightly worrying. 
How would it look from the outside of the Cardano community, to see that the most funded project doesn’t even bother to write complete proposals but continues to get funded regardless? To an outsider, it wouldn’t matter what the proposer has already built for the community, it would only matter that the system looks corrupt and will refuse to further engage with the entire ecosystem as a result of that.
While I understand the dcSpark team might be too busy building things to finish up writing proposals, I would suggest hiring a dedicated person for this task, thus ensuring the continuation of correctness in the experiment called Project Catalyst, the precursor of the governance module. What kind of governance will we be building?
I hope that if someone from the dcSpark team will be reading these assessments, they can see that this opinion is coming from an involved member in the ecosystem who has a deep appreciation for what they have been doing.
Considering the lack of details in the entire feasibility section, from the detailed plan and budget to the team description, I find it hard to decide on a fair rate for it. While judging only on the information provided, the maximum I would assess it would be a 2. But considering the fact that I am familiar with the work dcSpark has been doing, that goes way beyond a 5. So, in order to keep it fair, I will go with the average of the two, and for consistency with what I have mentioned above, I will round it down to a 3.
f6_assessments.q2:
The answers provided in the auditability section, although very succinct, do provide a minimum of understanding and clarity. The Cardano community would be able to assess the progress of the project by looking at the number of NPM downloads or the number of references for other implementations. Unfortunately, I have found no specification of where these metrics would be provided in a public, open manner. Would they be visible in the wallet itself, on the dcSpark website etc.?
Regarding the vision of success, the description provided is realistic and feasible, I foresee this integration being implemented by a lot of projects in the ecosystem.
Considering the fact that the questions have somewhat been answered, I will rate this section with a 4.

f6_assessments.q0: The "Catalyst SDK dRep support" proposal addresses the dRep improvement and onboarding challenge by updating Catalyst registration SDK to support dRep registration, adding dRep indexing to Carp, and implement dRep support inside Flint wallet. This proposal will be a direct and impactful step to progress dRep participation when the dRep role is active and can cast the votes on the project. Also by adding the support inside the Flint wallet will help in vote delegation and voting rewards.  The proposal outcome is not limited to only dRep but also can be used by any other projects that require Catalyst registration support or need indexing the Catalyst registration information making this proposal very impactful towards Catalyst and Cardano. There is no other risk except the standard engineering backlog and delays.
f6_assessments.q1: The DCSpark team will deliver SDK in early Q3 and indexer and flint support in late Q3. They would use 1 rust engineer and 1 part time project lead. Although the team could have provided the team member information, their past records make the project very likely to succeed within time. The budget breakdown could have been provided but the total budget requested look reasonable with the 3 lists of tasks they specify. The NPM link and GitHub provided by the team has more background information on the Catalyst registration. Without this implementation, dRep progress will be slow and not take off as scheduled.
f6_assessments.q2: The project success will be dependent on the successful implementation of SDK along with direct integration with other tools (NPM download or reference). Since the project plan is to complete within Q3 and their solution will be in use in Q4 and in time for next fund (fund 10), the community will be well aware if their project is complete and achieve its main KPI for this project. Alternatively the community can check their GitHub for their technical documentation or updates to their existing Catalyst registration SDK. The team has a clear understanding of the technical support needed to support dRep which is a crucial role for decentralization and help Cardano to reach its full potential for human collaboration.

f6_assessments.q0: To achieve the challenge setting's objective of increasing the number and number of origin countries for dReps, it is vital that the technical sophistication and blockchain integration of the Catalyst process advance. With supporting Github documentation and proper technical procedures, this is likely the case as the limited "community" setting of English language Telegram channels, Google docs and Youtube channels will not be able to support the growth and decentralization we are in this for. To allow the team at dcSpark to allow dRep support for wallets and create the foundations for technical documentation are an important step in this direction. I fully agree that this proposal fits the challenge setting very well.
f6_assessments.q1:
The well-known proposer team have been funded many times on Catalyst and have a track record of high quality delivery and exiting portfolio of Cardano improvements, sidechains, scale-ups, modular indexer and wallet (to name a few) that are impressive and speak for itself. 

The funding requested is entirely for the role of the Rust developer(s), thereby clear and very likely to lead to successful implementation of this proposal. The risk discussion is slightly superficial and could have centered more on the evolving dRep role, lack of funding for "Rust SDK fix critical CBOR encoding" proposal in Fund-9 Developer Ecosystem challenge. 
The proposers usually keep their proposals brief and could provide more details, but then again have a very well documented audit trail on Github and communicate regularly with the community via Youtube, Discord, Twitter and other channels.
Implementation is highly likely to be successful.
f6_assessments.q2: Successful delivery of the stated solution is not really my understanding of auditable performance metrics and milestones, but I agree that it will be easy enough to establish whether the goal has been achieved or not. Given the large portfolio of proposals and high workload of this team, I suggest that an audit of their entire portfolio should be considered, instead of going proposal by proposal, to keep interference in their work and workload of the challenge teams or auditors manageable. At the same time, to keep the Catalyst process fair, the same yardstick needs to be applied to well established teams, so there could possibly be improvements in the working relationship between Catalyst and well established, serial proposers, like a central reporting function or liaison.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal tries to update the existing Catalyst registration SDK to support dRep registration, add dRep indexing to Carp, and implement dRep support inside Flint Wallet. With the experience dcSpark have with prior Catalyst registration SDK and other successfully delivered projects, the chance of the project failing to be delivered is very low. However, many aspects of the proposal lack many important details, especially in the feasibility section. The poorly written proposal may hinder new voters that unfamiliar with dcSpark to give votes on the proposal, something that very unfortunate if happen.
f6_assessments.q1: The project does not provide detailed milestones to complete the project, and instead only gives the whole project a timeline to finish. In the budget section, the proposal only stated ‘All funds are put for developer cost’, without giving any breakdown. Even if the budget is only used for developer remuneration, the proposal still needs to give information on the hours needed to complete the project and their respective cost per hour/day. This information is important to determine if the requested budget is reasonable or not. The proposal only gives two roles involved in the project, rust engineer and project lead. Without giving any information on who is they. Let alone a LinkedIn/Github account of the team. Certainly information on the background, past projects, and relevant skills of core team members are needed for voters to know if the team can execute the plan.
f6_assessments.q2: The auditability of the project is easy through the public Github repository activity. The metrics used for tracking the project progress are two, directly with the number of NPM downloads, and indirectly used as reference. However, the proposal needs to elaborate more on how to measure reference. Due to the proposal's purpose being simple and straightforward, the defined success is the same, with the successfully released of the SDK that allows dRep support for future Catalyst rounds and integration in wallets.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is a necessary building block for the implementation of dRep delegation. By adding dRep registration and indexing to the existing catalyst registration this proposal can potentially have a global impact. The team presents a valid problem that needs to be solved. Their solution can add alot of value to the cardano ecosystem by creating and sharing the SDK tool with other projects.
f6_assessments.q1: I have confidence in the teams ability to succeed due to their previous proposal experience, their ongoing discussions with IOG, and because they created the original catalyst registration. For a project of the magnitude the budget seems reasonable but I would have like to seen it broken down more. The given timeline seems like a reasonable amount of time to complete work.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal provides a clear solution that addresses the problem statement. There is a roadmap which plans to build SDK tool in early Q3 and completion of the index and Flint support in late Q3. There are not many KPI's which will make this proposal a bit harder to audit. But there are metrics to define success such as completion of SDK tool and integration by other projects.

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea of this proposal is very interesting and could go a long way in helping voters find qualified dReps right on the wallet. This will require the proposed participants to be highly qualified and talented people.
If this proposal is implemented, it will be of great help to users who are used to using Flint wallets. I hope the team will develop this idea on other popular wallets like Yoroi.
f6_assessments.q1:
DcSpark is a very strong team in terms of technology on Cardano. I have seen their products like Milkomeda layer 2 solution, Flint wallet.
In my opinion, they are already so popular and influential that they won't need to write too much about the team members themselves.
f6_assessments.q2:
With a team that has a very good track record on Cardano and makes good products. They don't have to say much about what they need to do to complete the proposal.
Their job is to receive money and make products. Successful people often have their own way and dcSpark seems to be too.

solution: We will update our existing Catalyst registration SDK to support dRep registration, add dRep indexing to Carp and implement dRep support inside Flint Wallet
experience: Our team wrote the Catalyst registration SDK and was involved in the creation of the both the original Catalyst registration CIP along with its recent update for dRep support
